sen.j: 行幸（ぎょうこう、みゆき）とは、天皇が外出することである。
sen.e: Gyoko (Miyuki) means Emperor's going out
Gyoko (Miyuki) means Emperor's going out
"Gyoko" (Miyuki) is a Japanese term used to refer to the visit of the Emperor.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足自然な英語に修正しました。

sen.j: 目的地が複数ある場合は特に巡幸（じゅんこう）と言う。
sen.e: Visiting more than one place is called Junko.
Visiting more than one place is called Junko.
Visiting more than one place is called Junko.

sen.j: また、御幸（みゆき）と言う場合もある。
sen.e: Or also called Mityki.
Or also called Mityki.
Another Japanese word for this is "Miyuki."
sen.cmt: スペル自然な英語に修正しました。

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: The Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 皇后・皇太后・皇太子・皇太子妃の外出を行啓（ぎょうけい）/巡啓と言い、行幸と併せて行幸啓（ぎょうこうけい）/巡幸啓と言う。
sen.e: The going out of the Empress, Empress Dowager, the Crown Princess is called Gyokei, it is called Gyokokei/Junko (visiting more than two places) together with Gyoko (Emperor's going out)
When the Empress goes out, Empress Dowager, the Crown Princess it is called Gyokei, it is called Gyokokei/Junko (visiting more than two places) when together with Gyoko (Emperor's going out)

The term "Gyokei" or "Junkei" is used to refer to a visit by the Empress, the Empress Dowager, the Crown Prince, or the Crown Princess, while "Gyokokei" or "Junkokei" is used if the Emperor is also present for the visit.
sen.cmt: I'm sorry but this and the above translation of Gyoko do not work in English. "going out" is just a chokuyaku of 外出. "Visit" is more appropriate here, I think.Ref: http://books.google.com/books?id=IZhFf3hlgNoC&pg=PA196&dq=%22Gyokei%22++%22Gyoko#v=onepage&q=%22Gyokei%22%20%20%22Gyoko&f=false

sen.j: 単に「行幸啓」といった場合は、天皇と皇后が一緒に外出することを指す場合が多い。
sen.e: When it is said just 'Gyokokei', it often means the Emperor and the Empress going out together.
When just saying; 'Gyokokei', it often means the Emperor and the Empress going out together.
When just saying; 'Gyokokei,' it often means the Emperor and the Empress going out together.

sen.j: 行幸啓した者が外出先から帰ることを還幸（かんこう）、還啓（かんけい）、還幸啓（かんこうけい）という。
sen.e: It is called Kanko, Kankei, Kankoukei coming back from Gyokokei.
It is called Kanko, Kankei, Kankoukei when coming back from Gyokokei.
It is called Kanko, Kankei, Kankokei when coming back from Gyokokei.

sen.j: これら以外の皇族の外出はお成り（おなり）、お成りをした皇族が外出先から帰ることをご帰還（ごきかん）と言う。
sen.e: Except for above going out occasions of the Imperial families is called Onari, and it is called Gokikan coming back from Onari.
Except for the above occaisions, when the Imperial family goes out it is called Onari, Gokikan is coming back from Onari.
Except for the above occasions, when the Imperial family goes out it is called Onari, Gokikan is coming back from Onari.

sen.j: 但し、奈良時代などに於いては神功皇后の伊勢国行幸の様に行啓を行幸と言う場合もあった。
sen.e: However there was an occasion to call Kyoko, instead of Gyokei, when the Empress Jingu went to Ise province in the Nara period.
However there are occasions when it's called Kyoko, instead of Gyokei, for example, when the Empress Jingu went to Ise province during the Nara period.
However there are occasions when it's called Kyoko, instead of Gyokei, for example, when the Empress Jingu went to Ise Province during the Nara period.

sen.j: また、奈良時代などに於いて、行幸の際に宿泊するところを行宮（かりみや）と言う。
sen.e: Also it is called Karimiya to stay a night during Gyoko in Nara period.
It's also called Karimiya to stay a night during Gyoko during the Nara period.
It's also called Karimiya to stay a night during Gyoko during the Nara period.

sen.j: 行幸に際し、地名や社名が付く場合がある。
sen.e: It is often called with the name of the place or the name of the shrine doing Gyoko.
It is often called using the name of the place or the name of the shrine where Gyoko is being done.
It is often called using the name of the place or the name of the shrine where Gyoko is being done.

sen.j: 特に、目的地を持った行幸には地名が付くことがある。
sen.e: Especially Gyoko to the specific place is called with the name of the place.
Especially when Gyoko to a specific place, the name of the place is added.
Especially when Gyoko to a specific place, the name of the place is added.

sen.j: 例えば、住吉大社に行幸する場合は「住吉行幸」などと呼ばれる。
sen.e: For example, Gyoko to the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine is called 'Sumiyoshi Gyoko'.
For example, Gyoko to the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine is called 'Sumiyoshi Gyoko'.
For example, Gyoko to the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine is called 'Sumiyoshi Gyoko.'

sen.j: また、鎌倉時代の書物の中には「鞍馬寺御幸」などの表記も伺うことが出来る。
sen.e: Also there is a description of 'Kurama-dera Temple Goko' in the historical book of the Kamakura period.
Also there is a description of 'Kurama-dera Temple Goko' in the historical book of the Kamakura period.
Also there is a description of 'Kurama-dera Temple Goko' in the historical book of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 「東京行幸」は行幸と言う言葉を使い、その形態を装っているが、実質的な奠都と言う意味で用いられる。
sen.e: Tokyo Gyoko' seems to mean just an ordinary Gyoko, but it practically means the establishment of the capital.
Tokyo Gyoko' seems to mean just an ordinary Gyoko, but it practically means the establishment of the capital.
Tokyo Gyoko' seems to mean just an ordinary Gyoko, but it practically means the establishment of the capital.

sen.j: 独立行政法人国立印刷局が発行する官報には、天皇・皇后の行幸啓があった場合、下記の項目が掲載される。
sen.e: According to the government newsletter published by the Independent administrative institution, National Printing Bureau, the following items are run when there was Gyokokei of the Emperor and Empress.

According to the government newsletter published by an Independent administrative institution, the National Printing Bureau, the following items are run when there was Gyokokei of the Emperor and Empress.

According to the government newsletter published by an Independent administrative institution, the National Printing Bureau, the following items are run when there was Gyokokei of the Emperor and Empress.

sen.e: The name of the people who went to Gyokokei (Emperor's Gyoko, the Empress's Gyokei, the Gyokokei of the both)
The name of the people who went to Gyokokei (Emperor's Gyoko, the Empress's Gyokei, the Gyokokei for both)
The name of the people who went to Gyokokei (Emperor's Gyoko, the Empress's Gyokei, the Gyokokei for both)

sen.e: The place of the Gyokokei and the purpose of the visit
The place of the Gyokokei and the purpose of the visit
The place of the Gyokokei and the purpose of the visit

sen.j: 出門と還幸啓の日時
sen.e: The date and the time of the departure and the same of the Kankokei.
The date and the time of the departure and the same of the Kankokei.
The date and the time of the departure and the same of the Kankokei

sen.j: 具体的には、下記の例のように掲載される。
sen.e: It is run as follows in specific examples.
It is run as follows in specific examples.
It is run as follows in specific examples.

sen.j: 天皇陛下は、九月二十八日午後零時四十一分御出門、第百六十五回国会開会式に御臨場のため、国会議事堂へ行幸、同一時十九分還幸になった。
sen.e: The H. M. [His Majesty] the Emperor left (shutsumon) at twelve forty one in the afternoon on twenty eighth, September, to the Diet Building to attend (Gyoko) the hundred and sixty fifth opening ceremony of the diet, and came back (Kanko) at one nineteen in the afternoon on the same day.

The H. M. [His Majesty] the Emperor left (shutsumon) at twelve forty one in the afternoon on twenty eighth, September, to the Diet Building to attend (Gyoko) the hundred and sixty fifth opening ceremony of the diet, and came back (Kanko) at one nineteen in the afternoon on the same day.

The H. M. [His Majesty] the Emperor left (shutsumon) at twelve forty one in the afternoon on twenty eighth, September, to the Diet Building to attend (Gyoko) the hundred and sixty fifth opening ceremony of the diet, and came back (Kanko) at one nineteen in the afternoon on the same day.

sen.j: （平成18年10月2日月曜日付官報第4434号より引用）
sen.e: (It was quoted from volume 4434 of the government newsletter dated Monday, October second, Heisei 18.)
(Quoted from volume 4434 of the government newsletter dated Monday, October second, Heisei 18.)
(Quoted from volume 4434 of the government newsletter dated Monday, October 2, 2006)
